core_mechanics.description: These are the fundamental rules that govern most actions in the game.

d20_test.description: When you try to do something risky or opposed, you make a d20 Test.
steps: Add any relevant modifiers (usually an Ability Modifier and sometimes a Proficiency Bonus).
Compare the total to a target number (Difficulty Class for checks, Armor Class for attacks).
If your total equals or beats the target number, you succeed!

advantage_disadvantage.description: Sometimes circumstances make a task easier or harder.
advantage_disadvantage.advantage: Roll two d20s and use the higher number.
advantage_disadvantage.disadvantage: Roll two d20s and use the lower number.
advantage_disadvantage.cancellation: If you have both Advantage and Disadvantage, they cancel out and you roll normally.

abilities.description: Every creature has six Abilities that represent their physical and mental characteristics.
abilities.Strength: Measures physical power. Used for athletics, jumping, and swinging heavy weapons.
abilities.Dexterity: Measures agility, reflexes, and balance. Used for stealth, acrobatics, and firing ranged weapons.
abilities.Constitution: Measures health and stamina. Used to resist poison and survive harsh conditions.
abilities.Intelligence: Measures reasoning and memory. Used for arcana, history, and investigation.
abilities.Wisdom: Measures perception and insight. Used for noticing details, healing, and reading people.
abilities.Charisma: Measures confidence and force of personality. Used for persuasion, deception, and intimidation.

ability_modifiers.description: Your Ability Score gives you a modifier, which is the number you add to rolls.

proficiency.description: If you are proficient with something, you add your Proficiency Bonus to the roll.
applies_to: Attack rolls with weapons you're proficient with.
Ability checks using skills or tools you're proficient with.
The difficulty of saving throws against your spells.

skills.description: Skills are specific applications of your Abilities. You add your Proficiency Bonus if you are trained in that skill.

difficulty_class.description: The Difficulty Class (DC) is the target number for an Ability Check or Saving Throw.

example_dcs.Very Easy (5): Lifting a small rock, remembering a common rumor.
example_dcs.Easy (10): Climbing a rough rope, calming a normal horse.
example_dcs.Medium (15): Picking an average lock, tracking a creature through the woods.
example_dcs.Hard (20): Picking a complex lock, swinging from a chandelier.
example_dcs.Very Hard (25): Convincing a king to abdicate, climbing a sheer icy cliff.

combat.description: Combat is structured into rounds where each participant gets a turn.
combat.initiative: At the start of combat, everyone rolls a Dexterity check to determine turn order. Higher rolls go first.
combat.turn_structure: On your turn in combat, you can do three things:

actions.name: Move
actions.description: You can move up to your Speed (usually 30 feet for most characters).

actions.name: Action
actions.description: You can take one main action, like Attack, Cast a Spell, Dash, Disengage, Dodge, Help, Hide, or Search.

actions.name: Bonus Action
actions.description: You can take one special action if a class feature, spell, or feat grants it. You only get one per turn.

combat.reaction: You can also take one Reaction per round, which is an instant response to a trigger, like an enemy moving away from you (Opportunity Attack).

steps: Choose a target within your weapon's or spell's range.
Roll a d20 and add your Attack Bonus (Ability Modifier + Proficiency Bonus if proficient).
If the total equals or exceeds the target's Armor Class (AC), you hit!
Roll the damage dice for your weapon or spell and add your relevant Ability Modifier (for weapons).

armor_class.description: Armor Class (AC) represents how hard a creature is to hit. An unarmored person has an AC of 10 + their Dexterity Modifier. Armor and shields increase this number.

combat.critical_hit: If you roll a natural 20 on an attack roll, it's a Critical Hit! You get to roll all of the attack's damage dice twice.

spellcasting.description: Spellcasters can produce magical effects by casting spells.
spellcasting.cantrips: Simple spells that can be cast an unlimited number of times.
spellcasting.spell_slots: Powerful spells require the use of a limited resource called spell slots. You regain expended spell slots after a Long Rest.

steps: Choose a spell you have prepared and that you have a spell slot for.
Spells often require one or more components:
Verbal (V): You must speak magical words.
Somatic (S): You must make specific hand gestures.
Material (M): You must have a specific item, often held in a spellcasting focus.
Follow the spell's description to see what happens!

concentration.description: Some spells require you to maintain concentration to keep them active.
concentration.breaks_concentration: Taking damage, being incapacitated, or casting another concentration spell.
concentration.check: If you take damage, you must make a Constitution saving throw (DC = 10 or half the damage taken, whichever is higher) to maintain concentration.

resting.description: Adventurers need to rest to recover their strength and abilities.

short_rest.duration: At least 1 hour of light activity.
short_rest.benefits: Spend Hit Dice to recover hit points. Some class features recharge.

long_rest.duration: At least 8 hours of sleep and light activity.
long_rest.benefits: Regain all lost hit points. Regain all spent Hit Dice (up to half your total). Regain all spent spell slots and class features.

conditions.description: Conditions alter a creature's capabilities in a variety of ways.

common_conditions.name: Blinded
common_conditions.effect: Can't see. Automatically fails checks that require sight. Attack rolls against it have Advantage. Its attacks have Disadvantage.

common_conditions.name: Frightened
common_conditions.effect: Can't move closer to the source of its fear. Has Disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls while it can see the source.

common_conditions.name: Invisible
common_conditions.effect: Can't be seen. Is Heavily Obscured. Attack rolls against it have Disadvantage. Its attacks have Advantage.

common_conditions.name: Poisoned
common_conditions.effect: Has Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

common_conditions.name: Prone
common_conditions.effect: Crawling costs extra movement. Has Disadvantage on attack rolls. Attack rolls against it have Advantage if attacker is within 5 ft., Disadvantage otherwise.

common_conditions.name: Unconscious
common_conditions.effect: Incapacitated, falls Prone, drops held items. Attacks against it from within 5 ft. are Automatic Critical Hits.

healing_and_death.hit_points: Represent your health. At 0 HP, you fall Unconscious.

death_saving_throws.description: When you start your turn with 0 HP, you must make a Death Saving Throw.
death_saving_throws.success: Roll a 10 or higher on a d20. 3 successes stabilize you.
death_saving_throws.failure: Roll a 9 or lower. 3 failures mean you die.
death_saving_throws.critical: Rolling a natural 20 instantly lets you regain 1 HP.
death_saving_throws.critical_failure: Rolling a natural 1 counts as two failures.

healing_and_death.stabilizing: A creature can use a Healer's Kit or make a DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check to stabilize a dying creature. Stable creatures don't make death saves but remain unconscious.
